ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The AUC accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

1) Compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management rule (29 CFR §1910.119) and EPA's Risk Management Plan (40 CFR §68),
2) Implementation of the National Association of Chemical Distributors Responsible Distribution program,
3) Operator Function Specific and Emergency Response Training,
4) Operator Hazardous Communication and Personal Protective Equipment Training,
5) Preventative maintenance schedule,
6) Use of Chlorine Institute and Compressed Gas Association recommended technical specifications,
7) Use of effective operating procedures, written with the participation of facility operators, management, engineers and corporate managers,
8) Performance of a process hazard analysis at least once every five years with a third party consultant,
9) Implementation of a three year program internal auditing program,
10) Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism approved and implemented security program.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
No deaths, evacuations, recordable injuries and/or shelter in place do to a release of chlorine in the last five years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility has an emergency response plan, which has been reviewed and updated in August 2018 (emergency contact numbers are updated more frequently, once per calendar year at a minimum). The plan includes the following elements:
1) description of the chlorine process,
2) recommended first aid for chlorine and other chemical exposures,
3) a current list of all emergency equipment onsite and where such equipment is located,
4) a current list of onsite and offsite emergency response personnel and contact numbers,
5) detailed description of company personnel,
6) a current list of emergency and non-emergency government, public & private contact numbers,
7) procedures for reporting and handling the releases and s

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
Medley, Florida (EPA ID: 100000036631)
Executive Summary

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Allied Universal Corporation (AUC) accidental release risk management plan involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and maintenance and management practices. The elements of the plan are intended to prevent and minimize the accidental releases of extremely hazardous substances used on site. The AUC facility emergency response program involves the preparation of response plans that are tailored to the facility and the emergency response services available in the community. AUC's emergency response program has incorporated EPA and OSHA Emergency Response Program requirements and is modeled after the One Plan.

DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
AUC repackages chlorine into U.S. DOT specification cylinders and multi-unit tank car tanks (commonly known as ton containers). In addition, AUC manufactures a very limited amount of 10.5% by weight sodium hypochlorite. The facility includes a private rail sidetrack for unloading railcars. A production building, with an emergency scrubber, is used for packaging the cylinders and multi-unit tank car tanks. The sodium hypochlorite quality control testing is performed in the production building as well, with sodium hypochlorite production/line purge tanks, also connected to the scrubber, outside of the production building in a dedicated aboveground storage tank containment. The chlorine gas detection system as well as CCTV camera system continuously monitors all production and storage locations as well as the facility perimeter fence. The emergency shutdown system may be activated manually by an employee or automatically by the gas detection system as well as vibration sensors.
